Beautiful park but seems a bit overrated for me. Unfortunately the glacier point was closed during my visit — it could make this experience more interesting 😂. Nice views on the lower waterfall loop, valley loop. These and many other “hiking” paths you can easily do wearing heels and having a stroller with you. Mirror lake loop is just a little bit harder but also is more than accessible for people with zero fitness level. If you use a shuttle, you have more chances to become bored than tired.
Downsides:
- needs a reservation in advance
- sleeping spots in the park are booked out a few months in advance
- shuttles do not follow the schedule, are late and overcrowded
- toilets not in the main parking zone are extremely dirty and stinky

Absolutely beyond expectations of scale and beauty. This park is not to be missed. The waterfalls are incredible and the trees are fabulous and there is so much to do.  You could spend forever here and keep seeing new things. There are bathrooms at a few different places throughout the park. There's not great cell service so double check road and camp closures via park website  before you arrive and be prepared for delays due to wash outs and road damage which concentrates traffic heavily.
Absolutely beautiful- it’s one of my favorite places on Earth.
Was very beautiful, lovely views. Waterfalls were already dry in August and have very winding mountain roads but overall was nice.

Incredible park that's great for everyone from families to adventurers. Yosemite Valley itself is beautiful, and you could easily spend 3-4 days there just soaking in the beauty and enjoying hikes and quiet places. But the rest of the park - from the high country to redwood groves - is beautiful enough to have its own national park even if Yosemite Valley weren't there. Go, and spend several days exploring.
More water this year than ever before! The waterfalls were especially spectacular!

One of the greats! A must do! Get out there early and spend at least a full day or two! There’s a quick waterfall hike off the road and the two bigger waterfalls were on the trail that leads you to the halfdome trail. If you are doing halfdome get the passes. We didn’t get the lottery but heard sometimes people give up their passes at the half dome entrance. There were no passes when we got there but it was still an amazing hike. Take plenty of water if you are doing these hikes. Some get long. We did 14 miles going to the half dome entrance and back. It was still 2 more miles all up hill and back to do the half dome. Take rubber grip gloves too if you plan to do it. Visitor center area was great too. They have food and a store to buy souvenirs and snacks! Great experience here!

Amazing! Completely worth the visit and stay for a couple of days. So many trails from very easy to super hard. This year is probably the best to visit because it's not that crowded. We strated our long hikes before 7AM to avoid the crowds and who hot it can get in the early afternoon.

Best national park ever. The views are literally mesmerizing. Lots of easy hikes and moderate ones too for everyone in the group. Can't wait to be back! Think you need to register to hike some of the more challenging trails so will definitely be looking into that.
Beautiful landscapes& waterfalls. Lots of friendly people we met along the way. Great hiking trails & delicious food 😃

Beautiful park but it was way too crowded when we visited. There is also people just climbing where they shouldn't. No staff in sight. There was a few people trying to bike and I say trying because it was impossible in the busy areas.

I went to this place about a year and a half ago and I forgot to write a review about it. One of the best National parks in the US for good reason! It’s beyond beautiful and so many different hikes from simple to challenging. And great places to take photos if thats what youre into.
My favorite national park!
Will visit every opportunity I get! Absolutely breathtaking and one of the greatest natural wonders to ever encounter. The best of California nature! Photos are over time and multiple visits.
Visit twice. Love El Captain, Half Dome, waterfalls, and canyon. Visit in summer 2018, fall 2021, winter 2022, fall 2023

I was able to visit Yosemite national Park during winter. And I think I now highly favor visiting in winter time over visiting in summertime. There was way less people, and as long as you have the right cold gear, the experience can be just as wonderful. The amenities in the park were less favorable, there was no coin operated laundry and a lot of the shops were closed. But that's to be expected during the off season. Overall visiting Yosemite is just magical.

GORGEOUS. I'm pregnant and without a lot of stamina at the moment but my two kids and husband and I had such an incredible time walking the Lower Falls Loop, the Cooke Meadow loop, and the Mariposa Grove Giant trail! They are all easy and very accessible to almost any ability level. Tips would be to get to the park EARLY (before 8) for parking and access to everything. Stay parked all day until you're ready to explore outside of the valley. Get on the shuttles near the parking lot stops because they will mostly empty there. Don't miss the Mariposa Grove big trees loop or the tunnel view! It's beautiful. The only suggestion I have for the park is to get more shuttles running. Waits can sometimes be very long (an hour or more).

One of the best places to visit in California. Maybe the only place with such spectacular waterfalls that are concentrated in a small area!
Went in June 2023 and there were many many active waterfalls.
Parking is really problematic inside the park. A bunch of parking areas/lots are closed leaving limited parking spots throughout the park. Curry Village parking always fills up fast. Either plan to arrive early in the morning to get a spot at the parking areas near Curry Village or park someplace else and use the shuttle to commute between spots.
However, note that shuttles may be full or be running delayed so prepare accordingly. Worst case you could be left waiting for a shuttle to arrive.

Favourite place in all travels. The drive in from Tioga pass is stunning at every turn with steep pass, lakes, alpine meadows, rock formations and incredible views.
Drove through to waterfalls and Tunnel View
Hiked to giant tree groves
Stayed for couple nights in the Mariposa area in Big Tree Lodge. Real character property with a friendly old style resort feel
Would recommend
It’s beautiful to see the  waterfalls very relaxing to go hiking with the family

Have to see this NP which was the inspiration for all other national parks when President Lincoln signed the Yosemite land grant in 1864! Get an early start to have an easy drive around to the scenic stops! February is the best month to see the waterfalls and if you go in mid February you might even catch The Firefall when the sun hits Yosemite Falls and it looks like fire! There are easy hikes you can take to the extreme. Bring a bike, pack a picnic (highly suggested!) , or take the open tram ride  to have even more fun!! Easy to spend a whole day with the family!!

Yosemite National Park, the Alps of the United States and legendary home of Granite Giants and Giant Sequoias. During peak months Yosemite requires a day pass in addition to a park pass if you are not camping. With the park pass the day pass is $2. I like to stay at the snow play area right outside of the park if I am not camping inside. This makes the day pass extremely easy.

Entering from Tioga Pass there is miles of scenic stops, a visitors center, walking trails and places to put your toes into icy creeks or little lakes.  There is an entry fee per car to be admitted.  If you have an annual national park permit it is free admission.

Came all the way from Michigan to feel like a speck of sand, amongst the land. Went 12 hours on Sunday trying to catch my breath. What an absolute amazing place..

Sunrise at Glacier, then went to Bridalveil Fall. Then went down to the Tunnel View on my way to the valley floor, while checking out the merced river. Got a random bug to hike up to Yosemite point! Was able to go up and back in 4 hours.. Wow, if that wasn't a real hike.. Finished the day off eating a prime rib at Yosemite Ranch in Fresno.
Packed alot into one day being the only day I had while out here for work, but wouldn't trade it for anything. You locals are absolutely blessed to have a piece of the world like this near you!

What is there not to love about yosemite?  Oh the crowds!  Unfortunately stay out of the valley in the summer.   The Sierra are beautiful up over Tioga  Pass.  Glacier view is nice if you get there early.  By all means use your feet to get out on the trails!

Just a note that EVERYTHING at Tuolumne Meadows is closed this summer!
I cannot recommend the park enough, it is simply the best 4 days I have spent on vacation in 35 years of going abroad... Just amazing and awe inspiring - every turn makes your jaw drop....

Visiting Yosemite National Park in April brings unpredictable weather, where brilliant sunshine can quickly turn to rain and snow ❄️. It's essential to bring gear that's both rainproof and snowproof. Exploring Yosemite amidst wind and snow offers a unique charm, a kind of misty, mysterious beauty! It ignites an adventurous and curious spirit within you! It also inspires a longing to return and appreciate another type of beauty. The greenery peeking through the snow creates an unusual blend of green and white!
Amazing scenery!! May is great to avoid the big crowds. Great waterfalls and multiple swimming water holes nearby. I stay at Thousand Trails; location was ideal to explore Yosemite and surroundings.
One word, beautiful ❤️
Breathtakingly beautiful place.  I could site at Tunnel View or Glacier Point and admire the view for hours.

So pretty for this timer if you love the snow it’s the perfect time to go  and for the dinner all the restaurants are closed by 8 pm so  if y’all make it before that back yo your air b& b that would be awesome .
Yellowstone was beautiful! Lots of bison abd baby bisons crossing the road, beautiful scenery, Geysers to die for!!! Beautiful. If you're thinking about coming, do it!
There are few OTHER places on earth that contain so much natural beauty .... a true National Treasure.

Given how beautiful and popular the park is, it's disappointing that Yosemite National Park doesn't have comparable infrastructure, amenities, or housing.

I only have photos from half of my trip because Curry Village's freezing tents (I wish I brought a sleeping bag) don't have places to charge devices. If they did, I could show you scrambling around the boulder field at the bottom of the lower Yosemite Falls.

Or I could show the overpriced bike that I rented and how after it got stolen, I got lost trying to find my way back due to inadequate pedestrian infrastructure and signage (I can't imagine how hard it is for non-English speakers).

And it's not just me getting lost, I got stopped by fellow visitors asking for directions more than a few times. Maybe this wouldn't be an issue if the park had consistent cell coverage and we could use map apps.

I also take issue with how car dependent this park is. The busses are seasonal and only really exist in the valley. It's a similar story with bike access. For while there is 12+ miles of paved bike paths,  they are only in a portion of the valley and it feels like the park relegates cycling to an activity rather than a legitimate mode of transport.

The park deserves a major overhaul, especially given how expensive it is to go here.
Still I really recommend this park, I really want to go back.
Simply the greatest outdoors location of the  country. We hiked several trails. The sights are breathtaking

Huge National Park with so much to see and do. Hiking trails for all ability levels. We went in the spring and traffic was a breeze. The park was clean and well maintained. Plan on spending several days and use one of several lodging options available. You can stay outside the park and drive in but it's a big waste of time and if you pack in a full day of exploring, than the night drive can be hard.
Awesome backpacking loop. 10 lakes, Poly Dome lakes, then May Lake. Wrapped up the trip with a stay in backpackers campground in the valley. Beautiful. Inspiring.

We went on a guided hike through the Giant Sequoias and it was amazing!
After we were driven to multiple viewpoints along the route and took pictures from Tunnel View which had an incredible view of El Capitan, Half Dome and the three cathedrals. If there had been rain this year we would have also seen one of Yosemite's many waterfalls but there was nothing but a sad trickle that we could barely make out.

Don't expect cellular reception there by the way. You are pretty far from or have mountains blocking cell towers.

One of the best National Park to visit during winter. Very family and pet-friendly. Make sure you watch out for each other, and leash your pets at all time.

Tips: Make sure your tires are in good shape. Best to have tire chains, inflator (in case you need pump after deflate. ). Bring plenty of snack, water, and empty bottle because restrooms are tricky to get to sometimes. ALSO, bring a positive attitude with you, just because you have AWD doesn't mean you should drive like an Ahole. Share the road, watch for pedestrians, and follow laws (park rangers are serious here).

Possibly one of the most beautiful places on the planet, should be on everyone’s bucket list to visit at least once. Hard to describe other than the fact there is so much natural beauty. The photos tell the story better.

Beautiful views everywhere you look. If you go early the crowds aren’t too bad. We didn’t have to wait in line going in early but saw some long lines on our last day when we left the park around noon.

I don't even know how I could review this place. I went early in the year and half the roads were still snowed out, but I'm glad we didn't see it all so it will make a good destination later.
One thing that stuck out to me, since I can't describe the park itself. When I got back into my car at one common spot, an SUV full of a family swooped into the spot next to me. The driver nudged the teenage passenger and pointed, and the annoyed passenger started to protest, then happened to glance out the windshield sideways. I never thought I'd see someone look so different from one moment to the next. One moment annoyed teenager, the next three inches from the glass with an expression like a zombie.

this place will change you forever once you enter this valley you can never be the same again it is something you have to be here to witness the glistening snow on the mountains is magical and the meadows are breathtaking if you choose to come here love respect and protect this place to me and also for the people who lived in this valley long before us  at Yosemite you feel and see nature in a powerful way it’s tangible beautiful and almost overwhelming I’m proud to be here and to be preserving and working to keep meadows like the one in the picture thriving
Nothing compares to actually being in this great park in person! Definitely everyone should see at least one in their lives! We hope to come back and do some day hiking someday
Perfect time of the year...cool mornings for hiking and warm in the afternoon! Even got some autumn colors and the crowds were down.
Always beautiful,  always a great trip. I love it in the winter because there are no crowds!

It was amazing experience visiting this park during pandemic. Make sure you make a reservation before you go. Check the website for the update.
But the park by it self unbelievable beautiful. We went to bridal falls and one more. I feel up with energy and took a lot of pictures.
I've been here in the summer but this was our first winter visit. Went on a Saturday wasn't very busy and the scenery was amazing

Absolutely amazing National Park. I can’t say enough about the experience. I want to go back and enjoy more of it.

Great for families. The Lower Yosemite Falls hike is the easiest and really beautiful.

I went here using a guided tour for a one day trip since this place is quite far from the city (SF). This national park is so huge and breathtaking. A day is definitely not enough to explore the whole area, while every corner in this park is beautiful and worth exploring.

Next time, I'd definitely going to stay at least a night and just enjoy the serenity in this place.

Located at an elevation range from 648 to 3,997 m (2,127 to 13,114 feet) in the central California, Yosemite National Park was established in 1890 and has been managing by National Park Service since 1916. Almost 95 percent of the park’s 3,074 square kilometers (1,187 square miles) is classified as wilderness.

Designated a World Heritage Site in 1984, Yosemite National Park is one of the largest and least fragmented habitat blocks in the Sierra Nevada, and the park supports a diversity of plants and animals.

Yosemite National Park contains five major vegetation zones: chaparral and oak woodland, lower montane forest, upper montane forest, subalpine zone, and alpine. Of California's 7,000 plant species, approximately 50% occur in the Sierra Nevada and more than 20% are within Yosemite. The park contains suitable habitat for more than 160 rare plants, with rare local geologic formations and unique soils characterizing the restricted ranges many of these plants occupy.

The expansive forests and a variety of rich habitats within Yosemite National Park hold over 400 animal species. Black bear, mule deer, foxes, and other mammals can be found throughout the Yosemite Valley. At higher elevations, the endangered Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep can occasionally be spotted. Yosemite is also home to numerous bird populations, including California spotted owls or great gray owls.

Today, about 4 million people visit Yosemite each year, including hikers, climbers, campers, bikers, photographers and nature lovers of all kinds, charmed by the park’s awe-inspiring beauty and eager to experience one of America’s greatest natural splendors.

Yosemite National Park offers an abundance of activities and sightseeing destinations. The Valley is a 18 square kilometers (7 square miles) wide canyon with incredible rock formations, including El Capitan, the world's tallest granite monolith and one of the world's top rock climbing destinations. Yosemite Falls is the largest waterfall in North America with breathtaking views. Peak visitation at the falls is in the spring as it is comprised entirely of melting snow. The park is also known for its Giant Sequoia trees, which are estimated to be over 3,000 years old.

The park set a visitation record in 2016, while the number of visitors surpassed five million for the first time in its history.

Done the climbing there ,it was one of best things in life ,words never could express how great this place is ,but I feel it has become a tourist place mostly now now how it was 15-20 years ago it always packed now very hard to stop an take pictures only good thing about so many people is it pays for up keep of the park , they also no longer take cash to get in because of CV , it's now 35 instead of 20 dollars per vehicle, it's hard to really enjoy the peacefulness of this place unless you go off the roads an hit the back trails were only few go .

You seriously cant beat Yosemite. The gorgeous meadows, the massive granite rock features, the beautiful merced river. It is all just amazing .
If you want to go here make sure to check the weather and road conditions. During the winter roads May be closed.
Also expect large crowds at all the known locations.

Yosemite Valley was beautiful today! Crystal clear waters of green Merced river wound down the valley along the contrasting snow and sand. The view was absolutely magical. But for a huge holiday crowd and long pile of traffic with sparse parking slots, it was an amazing February visit! My favorite national park in the world!

There is simply so much to see and explore, it isn't about doing or seeing it all, but taking in the moment.  From breath taking views, to varying hikes, to white knuckle hair pin turn drive, this natural wonder is a must visit.

During our visit (October 2021), the shuttles were NOT running.  That meant many of the locations required more driving to get around the park but also meant many areas you had to walk further because many passage areas were closed to vehicle traffic.

In the end, the park is a place of wonder, soul fulfilling, and beauty.  There is evidence of past fires but also evolving change to allow nature to grow back.  It is and will always be nature first but with and concerted effort balance access.

Visit it, you will find some part that will put you in awe and wonder.

It’s grandeur is captivating not to mention it’s right in our backyard. Mariposa grove is a quick stop and shuttles run frequently on weekends. It’s a great place to test your hiking and climbing endurance. The falls had little water since summer was over when we went up.
Everything was beautiful. Some roads and trails closed due to the fire but overall still enjoyed 7 full days of trails and hikes and nature
One of the most beautyfull place I ever vistited.
A wonderful place to visit, gorgeous nature, and a lot of good small breweries.

Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. This place is huge therefore plan well before you visit.

Our fav National Park...just too iconic to be topped. Some feel like it's over-rated due to crowds, but with so many cool hikes and the beauty of the vley floor...have to see it at least once!

We have done so many things here and have SOOOO many pucs...can't choose which to share.

The 4 of us hiked Half Dome in Aug 2021 (kids age 7 & 8 -- updated to add @Matlock.Rock for those that have been wondering how/why) and we plan to do it again 8/9/22! 🤙

Kiddos did love the Junior Ranger program also... Rangers really took their time with the kids. Definitely worth the tiny investment of time and barely $$!

The coolest place I’ve ever been to. Aside from the naturey things there are some places to get food, a shopping center, a post office, pretty much a little town. Make the the drive from wherever you are and go visit!!

Wow! Where do I start.
It’s hard to look away off these cliffs and waterfalls.
Great trails, not easy but you can menage.
We stayed in camp 4, and enjoyed every minute there.
Cellular reception is good in the valley, not when you go up.
Beautiful park, one of my favorites. Can be very crowded, but the veiws and scenery Are worth it.

Five stars for the beauty of this place. It was very crowded today and very hot or we would have spent longer there. Still worth it though and the entry fee is very reasonable considering it is valid for 7 days. All in all a mesmerising, stunning national park and a highlight of our trip.

Heard about it, seen it on TV, seen it in films, looked at pictures in magazines; but nothing prepares you for seeing it in the flesh! Absolutely unbelievable! The scale and beauty of one of nature's finest creations has to be experienced to be believed. The hiking trails take you to places you can't see from the valley floor. Here, the wonders continue. Just go and see it!
This place is breathtaking. Photos don’t to justice. Vernal falls/Nevada falls, great experience. I don’t know why people drink while hiking, but that’s just me, I guess.

One of my favorites to forest bath. Best times with my bestie hiking in a major rainstorm in the middle of winter 🥳🤣🥰. Stay hard!!
Highly recommend for anyone that loves a challenge outdoors 💪
Hope future and current generation take care of this gem!

Always as beautiful as you can see for your entire life.   I never get bored of the views.  Only thing I hate here is too crowdy.  Luckily been there in Friday, hardly any crowd.  Kids loved playing in badger pass in snow.  Totally worth the drive.
Truly breathtaking. The range of natural wonders here are truly spellbinding.  Waterfalls, granite monoliths and stunning scenery at every turn. An absolute must.
I enjoyed my time in Yosemite National Park! Got to experience such beautiful sights!
Nothing like Yosemite in Sierra. If you have not entered the park from east (Tioga Pass) then please plan for it. It is open in summer till fall (for 6 months).

The beauty is sooo astonishing and overwhelming.  It's one of the greatest place I have camped and hiked and enjoyed the crispy fresh air within the woods.
The park offers great spot for camping,  accessible bathrooms and plenty of parking spots.

We drove from Sunnyvale city to Yosemite. Its an amazing place. Roads are twisty and windy so drivers to be careful.The View and scenery make everything worth it. We are lucky as it was very bright and suggest to be there before 10 am to enjoy the most. This place is feast for your eyes and must visit place with family specially kids can enjoy but be careful with toddlers near to the falls. Spend at least one night here to see the milky way painted across the night sky. There are lot off points to watch and you can cover all the places with the help of map. The stay can be expensive if you have not planned in advance. Overall its a stunning place.

Such an enchanting place. Perfect for hiking and sight seeing or simply to get away. $35.00 for a 7 day pass. Consant rangers driving by incase you need help. Really cold during this time of year so I'd recommend you wear extra layers. If you wanna see snow go to glacier point!

This is my favorite park in all of CA. There’s a reason why it’s usually so crowded- everything here has a wow factor to it. I recently got talked into purchasing an annual national parks pass so I’ve visited this place 3 times in the last month. It’s a playground for anyone who loves the outdoors- I’ve gone rock climbing here, hiking, and just simple sightseeing. I’m hoping that if covid restrictions loosen, I can plan a nice camping trip or a backpacking trip for next year.
I loved coming here , it was so magical. There are so many trails ! It was very clean . There are bathrooms everywhere .  Parking when it is busy is a bit of a headache though .
Simply stunning 😍 👌 Majestic scenes abound!!

Signing up early for a camping spot in the valley is worth it, it's so awesome to be deep within the trees surrounded by granite giants. Every peek through the canopy is magic, it's a beautiful place with tall trees and tall walls. These photos are all taken by me and yes it is that gorgeous.

Perfect weather!! Beautiful. To many people but manageable.
One lane road and construction so plan extra time.

I can’t even begin to explain how magical it is to visit Yosemite National Park. This is a piece of earth that I am so lucky to have witnessed. It’s a place where no wifi connection exists, which in turn forces you to connect with Mother Nature. If you want to take it all in, I’d suggest planning and staying several days inside the park, so plan wisely. The days I visited were quite pleasant, not too hot but not too cold (late May-early June). I did take my dog Duchess with me, which was quite lovely, but I’d recommend leaving your pets at home to enjoy the adventures fully; there are several popular hikes where pets are not allowed, so something to think about. I did need to reserve my entry pass well in advance, which was suitable for three days. The park was not jammed packed with tourists, which was incredible for two things, 1. more available parking and 2. taking pictures without being photobombed. With covid restrictions being lifted, I won’t be surprised if they allow more people in the park. I want to return and trek parts of the park where I could not go with my dog, like the half dome. Please visit this park if you want to disconnect from the hustle and bustle of the city and if you are down to reconnect with mother nature at a another level. ⛰☀️🌲🐻😍🥾🥾🪵🌳🌾🌊

Visiting this place is a must do, on anyone's bucket list.... we were amazed out how beautiful big and inspiring this place was big skies, falls, mountains and country....epic.You must swim in a river before leaving!!!! We saw a bear!!!

The tunnel that leads you to the exit has a breath taking view. I truly enjoyed walking through the park, climbing the rocks to get to the waterfalls. It was awesome. Great place for adventures and beautiful scenery.

The drive down to the valley was terrifying but worth it. The mountains feel so big surrounding you. Waterfalls everywhere. Saw bears and deer. Hiked clouds rest which felt busy enough to feel safe without feeling too busy to be annoying. Everyone on trail was super friendly.

One of the most impressive National Parks, not only in California, but on the West Coast. Spectacular views, granite walls that make you feel so small, and so much nature to bask in. Easily one of my favorite places ever. I was able to spend 4 days in the park in the fall/early winter and the colors were spectacular. Had some snowfall on one of the days which easily added to the beauty of the park. To be expected, the weekends were nearly doubled with people so I highly recommend getting to the park during a weekday to take in as much as you can without the crowds.

The park itself is beautiful but DO NOT BUY ANY TOURS HERE!!! I just spent $240 on tour tickets and was turned away when I arrived. New rule for cars entering park. When I called customer service rep Emma was unpleasant and stated no rescheduling or even refunds.

One of the most visited national parks in US. The mountains are huge and breathtaking. Lot of hiking trials. And this is like a shrine for all rock climbers. The El Capitan is so majestic that you can see for hours. Lot of parking slots. But get crowded and full frequently. Planning in advance and booking camping spots makes things easy. Whether in summer or winter, this is one of the best place to visit. The roads leading to the valley are breathtaking and beautiful.

Absolutely beautiful park with incredible views. The Lower Falls loop has a great view of the Yosemite falls and lets you get pretty close to the fall itself. The Tunnel View area lets you see nearly the whole park while not having to go too far out of your way. If you happen to forget anything or want to see what events are going on, the village area has you covered. There's something for everyone here. :)

Came here late June. Reservations are needed to drive through Yosemite, make sure to plan ahead. This place is big! Prepare to hike a lot, but there are bikes available. There is a free shuttle bus that takes you from park to park. Bring lots of water for the hike, they do have a small mini market store to buy food, water, etc. Make sure to bring a camera! This place is beautiful! Saw a bear, antelope and a coyote. This place gets crowded, come early for the pictures.

Yosemite is the prettiest place on earth. You will fall in love with everything you see here… the trees, their canopies; the falls, their slo-mo descend; the mountains, their rocky grandeurs; the streams, their naughty laughter..!!! It’s sheer love. I recommend visiting the visitor Center first and identifying your trail. If you’re coming here from near or far, plan to camp for at least 3 days to get a glimpse of some of the nicest valleys, meadows and glacier tops. The hikes can be easy to difficult; choose wisely. Wear comfortable pair of shoes. There are restrooms at some of the prominent viewpoints. Bring your own food but keep it packed. Do not attract the bears.

Absolutely breathtaking. Nothing comparable in the UK in terms of scale, and is undoubtedly impressively beautiful. Worth spending three full days here if you can. Bring suitable hiking shoes if you're planning to go high up! Note there is a $35 entry fee but is valid for a week and worth every penny. Bumped into a guy from New Jersey here who said that Yosemite was the most beautiful place he's been to, so that must count for something I reckon.

Best place to be during the 4th of July on one was there and it was absolutely gorgeous... The skyscraper trees were amazing the waterfalls we awesome. The trails could have you lost for years..a beautiful back round history to go with a beautiful park scenery

It's Yosemite, what more can I say! Hiked the John Muir trail up to Clark's Point as the Mist Trail steps to Vernal Falls were closed for trail maintenance. Stunning as always, though smoky as I climbed higher. This was my second time at the park but the first time I've left the valley in search of other trails. Check out Tenaya Lake, it's worth the drive. Unbelievably beautiful high altitude lake with a trail running around it and beaches at either end.
Completed the clouds rest hike - definitely worth the hike but got pretty winded. Would recommend proper gear and starting early! We got caught in the dark and got a little lost!

Absolutely breathtaking! I could’ve stayed there forever. The amount of hikes, waterfalls, and views are endless. Give yourself time to explore and time to recover in between long hikes as they can be tiring.

I used to visit Yosemite with my family when I lived in so cal as a child. I had the pleasure of visiting again, this time from the EC and with a wife. This place was as beautiful as I remembered it. I have visited dozens of national parks and Yosemite sits in top 2. Our May visit was met with a perfect weather and view. Only downside was that they were burning the trees so it was bit unsightly in some locations with a strong burning odor.

What can I say, it's YOSEMITE!! Beautiful doesn't begin to describe it. All around amazing views. As a local though, I'd say the amount of people visiting is very stressful. The traffic is as if you're downtown LA. The visitors drive very dangerously. They put themselves and everyone else in danger when they walk across the roads and stand in the roads. Outside the Valley they drive too fast and put wildlife in danger. It took me almost 20 minutes to find parking in Curry Village. I thought I was coming at a time when there would be less people (early October). I guess that's a national park for ya. It's overwhelming. John Muir is turning in his grave. #restoreyosemite
Wow what an incredible place it's a must to visit, stunning scenery and wildlife. I missed them but others saw a mama bear and cub

I kept coming here for Camping and hiking. Last visited, we did HALF DOME and many medium trails. Half dome by itself self probably takes 7-13 hours round-trip, depends on how strong and how fast you are.

At Yosemite Valley, There were FREE Shuttle bus operates all year from 7 AM to 10 PM, to parking lot, store, camp grounds and major visiting points. It was very convenient!

Due to COVID-19, make sure you check all information before visiting.
One of the best National Park in America
Always stunning scenery. Colors are changing but not at their peak yet. Loved being there for a week, camping in Upper Pines Campground. 💕💕

Incredible experience to escape into nature! Probably my favorite national park that I've been to! I've hiked Half Dome and Cloud's Rest and both are filled with scenic wonder. Awesome place for any age to get out and enjoy the most beautiful nature.

At every turn I was speechless this place is packed with picturesque views. I cannot stress enough how beautiful. My hats off to John Muir, Theodore Roosevelt, and everyone else that made this a national park. The only negative about my experience was that I did t stay more than two days. I will definitely love to visit again.
It was first time visiting on fall. Really beautiful!!
Breathtaking place with beautiful nature scenery and wildlife. Definitely one for the hiking bucket list.

One of the most beautiful places I've ever seen. But always super crowded.

Update May 2023.   So much water!! The waterfalls are raging.  Many campgrounds are open though some have several with flooded sites.

What’s not to love about a National park? Yosemite has lodging, hiking, climbing and relaxing to fit every kind of traveler/adventurer. Planning in advance is crucial if you requiring lodging or campsite. The last trip was spent in a tent cabin with bear locker outside. It was frugal, yet clean and met our needs. Trails were clean and varied. Enjoyed the hearty foods at lodge. If you only had time to journey there for a single day, it’s a beautiful area of the US.

Back to nature at one of the most beautiful places in the world!
It’s one of my favorite places to walk thru the forrest or any other of the quiet ways to move about this awesome landscape!
An overall immersive experience, both figuratively and literally, my mind is inclined to slip into meditation!
Small lakes and creeks provide natural swimming or wading spots, good to keep in mind after hiking and climbing the hills, rocks and mountains!
Preplanning may be necessary before heading thru the gates. Visitors who are not with a tour operator or private group, will need to arrange their own permits, reservations and fees.
For daytime adventurers, reservations are required and will cost $35 per non-commercial vehicle and $30 for motorcycles.
Individual entry hikers, bike riders and non-commercial bus or vans with more than 15 passenger seats are charged at $20.00 per person.
Commercial operations should know to preplan accordingly. Otherwise, the group will be turned around and sent to the nearest shuttle bus stop.
Once inside, the Yosemite Valley is a large, open area to navigate freely. Exclusions apply for campsites and facilities used with private permits, as well as restricted park personnel areas.
A note of caution is to be safe on rocky cliffs, protect the skin from excessive sun and watch out for the wildlife! Campers will need to prevent food scavenging bears from stealing their supplies with the use of lockboxes. The sturdy containers are usually included with permitted campsites.
The village is in sync with nature. Park facilities, cabins, shops and lodging, keep a natural appearance. Urban commercialism is obviously not acceptable here! The Village Store may not offer all the typical city supermarket stock, tho has a modest offering of essentials, so anyone can be a happy camper!
Last but not least, there’s been concern about a fire burning near the famous Mariposa Grove of giant sequoia trees. Kudos to the firefighters for holding their ground to protect the trees and to my colleague Mark for the updates!
A park advisory has issued updates and information on the fires. It also mentions how preventative backfires have been used to minimize the ongoing danger.
So my hope is that wildfires will be stomped out with this footnote, as we take it all in stride!

There are so many hiking trails for every level of hiker or young child to enjoy. My family and I are so appreciative and thankful for the opportunity to enter the park without reservations because of the pre-six am entry option. The views are AMAZING. Our family plans on traveling to Yosemite National Park over and over again!
Not sure there is a better place in the world to rediscover the best of America.  Go outside and treat yourself to fresh air, amazing views, and rejuvenate your soul!

Yosemite is one of my favorite places to be. There's an absolute presence to the sheer mountains when you're in the valley. We were up before sunrise every day and saw a coyote, bobcat, two bears, and a bunch of deer in two days. The waterfalls look a little sad due to the drought, but it wouldn't stop me from going on all the hikes. We hiked up vernal falls, Taft point, sentinel dome, lower Yosemite falls, and glacier point.

A must for your bucket list. I was not that eager to go but after driving to the town of Mariposa, I said " what the hell" and kept driving to the park. I was not even interested in going, but I was bored.

It is one of the most inspiring and breathtaking places that I have ever visited. These pictures do not show the grandiosity of these rocks and mountains. Luckily for me, the snow was melting producing a contrast between ice, waterfalls, and vegetation that was amazing. There were waterfalls everywhere and some were streaming down the rocks and into the river.

No drones are allowed, but using one would have been amazing.

Beautiful park. There is road construction going on currently in the valley, so be prepared for that. They are also opening up additional capacity after reducing it for COVID-19, but have not brought back the shuttle busses, so expect lines coming into the park.
So vast, so serene. It's a place where everybody can enjoy their own way and pace.
Great National Park! Loved it!
I love this place! Photos just don’t do it justice. In person, everything is ginormous and glorious!

Definitely worth a visit!
In summers it is mandatory to reserve your spot before visiting the park on weekends & public holidays..

The greateat national park ever.
So sad to see all trees burnt due to the wildfire in 2022
Amazing park, but be wary of the summer months when they conduct controlled burns as they do release a lot of smoke which may not be good for those with a sensitive respiratory system.
Truly enjoyed visiting Yosemite.  A must-see, visit!l when you can.
A site to behold! Stay for a couple days so you can take your time doing hikes and taking in the views. Must see the tunnel view point!

My uncle painted a painting that I have been looking at ever since I was a little girl. It is of Yosemite and all of my life I had been saying that I have to go to where this painting was inspired from. My long-awaited trip across Country van camping led me to Yosemite National Park. I can't believe I finally made it and it is amazing, breathtaking, awe inspiring. No painting, no picture and, no words can describe this Beauty accurately.

Breath taking nature! The views are awesome and so many trails everywhere. Earlier the better because traffic gets backed up upon entrance for any big landmark. Most stops have port o potty’s but they’re gross so prepare for that (but at the least they’re)

This is a place I always enjoy going, just to imagine that so many people in the area that haven't gone here it's crazy!! I have been here so many times and still I feel like it's not enough, so many places to go and the park itself it's huge! Over all you must visit the park if you come to California! And still 2023 I love this place.

Blew my expectations out of the water.  We traveled with our three kids ages 13, 11, and 7 and were still able to see spectacular sites.  Already planning a trip back for a week long backpacking expedition

There's never a bad time to visit Yosemite. The Valley floor took my breath away this time, as I had never seen it so late in the year. The added bonus of a November visit is that the park was far less crowded than in the summer months.
